instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
Hello. So, i got this machine not turning on. there is green light on charger that goes orange, and it responds to a smc reset. i got the board out of the case, and i saw <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> with corrosion in pin 8. i took it out, and remove <CAPACITOR>C6100</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C6101</CAPACITOR>. i try to reprogram <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> but its shorted. then i take another <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> put a proper rom, and put it in the board again. pin 8 of <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> was blown out, so i run a wire to <CAPACITOR>C6100</CAPACITOR> pin 1.alright, after this whenever i plug power, it powers once and shut down, i notice this because i conected a usb mouse and i see it lights up once. then i took measurements of <SIGNAL>SM_SLP_S4_P</SIGNAL> and it was coming up and going down at once. ive already replaced <CHIP>U6101</CHIP>, <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, and <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and still the same issue.

in the forum it says that it wont turn on without battery, and the battery was screwed; so i put one from a 2013 machine that i had lying around. should i get one from a 2015 machine; or this one does just fine?

and
So where do i go from this?.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
The board should start by itself with charger only.
Bu sure to use original 60/85W Magsafe 2 charger.
Also check traces and all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors; there are more than 20...

Where did you get new BIOS?
I think we already have some link posted on the forum...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: with charger only the board acts like its dead, there is no pulsing on charger only. Im using a ORIGINAL 85W magsafe2 charger. ill check the traces later. the BIOS, i got it from a ramdom post at ghostlyhacks, i took it and cleared the ME region. if you have one that you are sure that works, and share it with me i would highly apreciate it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: This one will boot without the battery if the charger is OEM. 2013 battery will not work in 2015 so do not use 2013 battery. Post <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> voltage with the charger only and check all that 2informaticos suggested

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is 3.3v. The SPI traces and resistors are fine!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
Did you try to start in SMC bypass mode?

Keep the battery out for the moment.
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?
Post <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for reaction (drop pulse) at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
If yes, chek for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
Dunno how to start SMC Bypass Mode.

i have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, steady 3.3V on both.

<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> =3V

<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>= 3.3V

<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>= 2.4V

<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>= 3.3V

What do you mean with ''trigger", i dont get it sorry.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
well, i figure out about the SMC Bypass Mode and the ''trigger''.

When trying SMC Bypass it does nothing at all.

when i trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> drops for instant; and the mouse blinks once...moreover <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> , <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> , <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> goes high when i trigger <SIGNAL>SOMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
OK, then all S3/0 voltages should pulse too; check if any not.
Also check for pulse at pin 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
All S3/S0 rails pulse when i trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

there is a pulse in pin 7 and 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
Do you get pulse at VCORE too?

I always recommend to reball SMC on corroded boards.

Also try another BIOS; search the forum...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: I?ve tried two other bios already and nothing. i dont get anything at <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>. Do i reball SMC now or where else do i check?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: Since i have no <SIGNAL>PPVCC_SO_CPU</SIGNAL>, i inspected <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7320</CHIP>. and well it seems the rail of <SIGNAL>CPUVR_PHASE1</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CPUVR_PHASE2</SIGNAL> are shorted to ground...i measure there 0 in diode mode. i have another board here and i measure 50 there!. should i replace <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7320</CHIP> only, or should i replace the four mosfets too??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
I bet all the CPU MOSFETs are good.
Lift the CPU coils; if the short remains on the CPU side, then is dead.
Less than 0.1% still possible to be <CAPACITOR>C1031</CAPACITOR>, not CPU...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: Well, it seems its dead then, i dont have the will or the equipment to replace the CPU. the short its in CPUside. anyway, just wondering but can I test the display in a 15 inch machine?. since its dead, i was wondering how to test it...i have one macbook pro 2015 15 inch and i was wondering if the 13 inch display could be tested there...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: Does anybody knows if the 13'' will work on a 15'' of the same year?, i wanna know to see if i can teset the display...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
